comments:
Scenario: Java application calls C++ through the JNI. Lots of data passed from
Java to C. Desire is to debug the C++ code using gdb, while the Java code is
running under eclipse.

Where this works: Works without a problem on Windows XP with the .Net debugger,
devenv. I start the java application and set a breakpoint after it has
successfully loaded and initialized the C++ shared library. Then have devenv
attach to the running process, set breakpoints in native code, and continue. At
this point eclipse can step/run normally, with devenv taking control whenever
one of its breakpoints is hit.

Where this does not work: On Linux (Red Hat or Suse 9, gcc 3.3.3). GDB can
attach to the running process and set breakpoints, but after resuming eclipse
has problems. Sometimes it reports "Timeout waiting for packet" and sometimes
just hangs. GDB continues to get "Program received signal SIGUSR2, User defined
signal 2"

can you be more specific as to what you think might be wrong with Eclipse 
itself?  Its just a Java app.

Might have something to do with how debuggers attach to other processes on Linux
... perhaps some conflict with two trying to do so concurrently? Just an
uneducated guess. It would be nice to have a simple JNI-based program to give
you to demonstrate the problem. If there is not enough info here please let me
know and I'll try to get something together.

If anything, this is probably an issue with the Java debugger in Eclipse timing
out while the native code is being debugged. Moving to JDT debug component.

Are there any entries in the .log file associated with this timeout problem? 
It sounds like the Java debugger is trying to communicate with the VM, which 
is not responding in a timely fashion, likely because it is being 
debugged/suspended at the same time via the C debugger.

Yes, from a couple different runs. I'm including them all just in case there is
something of value with the out of order packets. During the second run ~12:27 I
was telling gdb to continue and it was getting sig 2.

The timeout exceptions show that the target VM is no longer responding to the 
Java debugger front end. I might expect this while the VM is suspended at a 
breakpoint in the native/C++ code. However, once resumed, I would not expect 
this.

traces.message: Timeout occurred while waiting for packet 198.
Timeout occurred while waiting for packet 461.
Timeout occurred while waiting for packet 460.
Timeout occurred while waiting for packet 462.
Timeout occurred while waiting for packet 466.
Timeout occurred while waiting for packet 469.
